thread.title: High-end California restaurant reaches six-figure settlement with prosecutors over tilapia dish
thread.title_full: High-end California restaurant reaches six-figure settlement with prosecutors over tilapia dish

author: Joseph Serna
title: High-end California restaurant reaches six-figure settlement with prosecutors over tilapia dish
text:
High-end California restaurant reaches six-figure settlement with prosecutors over tilapia dish fish Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times Tilapia is tossed into a net for harvesting at Pacific Aquafarms in Niland, 30 miles east of Indio. A restaurant in Santa Clara County was serving the fish but charging customers for cuts of a pricier dish. Tilapia is tossed into a net for harvesting at Pacific Aquafarms in Niland, 30 miles east of Indio. A restaurant in Santa Clara County was serving the fish but charging customers for cuts of a pricier dish. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times) Joseph Serna says it specializes in artisinal Mediterranean cuisine. Its menu says that the Petrale sole is wild caught and is served with lemon, capers, dill, saffron, parmesan risotto and grilled asparagus. It costs $31.95. Russia denies that intelligence agents were in contact with Trump's campaign team. 100,000 people living downstream of the Oroville Dam are now allowed to go home . Enrique Marquez Jr. didn't take part in the San Bernardino shooting on Dec. 2, 2015. When the pastor at a Texas church urged his congregation to embrace refugees, 300 members left .

Caption Dam operators now hope to lower Lake Oroville by 60 feet 
Even after Lake Oroville's water level is reduced by a targeted 50 feet, water managers intend to further drain the reservoir so that it can absorb major rain storms and spring snowmelt, according to state planning documents. 
Even after Lake Oroville's water level is reduced by a targeted 50 feet, water managers intend to further drain the reservoir so that it can absorb major rain storms and spring snowmelt, according to state planning documents. Caption Helping refugees in the buckle of the Bible Belt 
An evangelical pastor loses some Republican members of his flock when his Fort Worth church bucks President Trump and welcomes refugees. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)
